candidates.title: Update Cargo.toml
candidates.body:
Linked_hash_map is unsound for releases <= 0.5.2. Bumping this to `^0.5.3` 

[Advisory](https://github.com/RustSec/advisory-db/issues/298)

candidates.title: RUST-413 Implementing ObjectId spec tests
candidates.body:
1. Timestamp already tested.
2. counter overflow tested by creating an objectID with MAX counter and making sure the counter is MAX. Then created another objectID which incremented the counter to MAX + 1 and made sure it is reset to 0. Found a bug in the code. Fixed that.
3. No fork in Rust.

candidates.title: RUST-484 Add a test lock and move integration tests
candidates.body: This PR adds a test lock because of concurrency issues (multiple tests reading/writing from/to counter in an object and all running on the same thread). To be able to use the same lock in src/oid.rs and the tests in src/tests, the tests module had to be moved to src/tests

candidates.title: Bump dependencies for hex and md5 crates
candidates.body:
- hex -> 0.4.2
- md5 -> 0.7.0

The dependency updates should be innocuous and bring us to the latest version of these crates.

candidates.title: RUST-454 Implement error case BSON corpus tests
candidates.body:
[RUST-454](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/RUST-454)

This PR implements the "decode errors" and "parse errors" sections of the BSON corpus spec tests.

As part of implementing the parse tests, there ended up being far more changes (both in implementation and API) than I would have liked, but I believe they were all necessary. The changes stem from the fact that our current extJSON parser would not fail if extJSON wasn't formatted properly--it would just parse it as a document. The spec's indicate we should actually reject such inputs, which required adding failability to all the extJSON parsing mechanisms (`From<Value> for Bson => TryFrom<Value> for Bson`).

To implement these changes, I started by trying to modify `from_extended_document` to shake the boat as little as possible, but I quickly realized that doing the error checking there would require a ton of boilerplate. I instead opted to leverage `serde` as much as possible by defining models for the various extJSON representations of things, while still leaving `from_extended_document` around so as to not break the `serde` implementation.

From an API perspective, I needed a new error type for extJSON parsing errors. To that end, I added an `extjson` and `extjson::de` module to house that type. In the future, I think we could add further generic functions for extJSON deserialization/serialization in there too.

candidates.title: RUST-447 Standardize API with other serde libraries
candidates.body: This PR updates the bson API language to use "serialize" and "deserialize" in place of "encode" and "decode" respectively.

candidates.title: RUST-346 Implement bson corpus spec tests
Cleanup deps
candidates.body:
- Remove unused dependencies (libc, md5)
- Replace the time crate with std equivalent
- Replace the byteorder crate with the std's `{to,from}_{le,be}_bytes` functions on integers
- Some formatting
